TopicTitle: What's the "stupidest" fun you've had in KSP?

Articles.Content:
Have you ever done something that wasn't productive at all but was somehow really entertaining? 

A couple random examples of mine would be messing around with a few Cupcake inspired ion landers on Minmus, building grasshopper-style VTOL rockets and practicing suicide burns, or building a massive rocket to see how quickly I could impact the moon (25ish minutes)

Watched a Scott Manley video where he tried to rover the Dres canyon. I built a wide and long, low sitting buggy, and had a go. Sent multiple missions and tried my best. The results were much like the video but great fun was had.

I'd say most of my time in KSP is unproductive in terms of advancing a career save, expanding a sandbox setup or even expanding my "fleet" of active craft.  I do a lot of derping about and the productive stuff happens almost by accident when one particular derp happens to turn into something good!  But I guess all the derping about is, in it's own way, productive;  at least you gain design tricks and put in some more hours of pilot training.

Some of the most fun I've had with the vanilla game was sending a lander + rover to Moho trying to do some rock crawling and ending up instead rocketing down a kilometers-long slope trying desperately not to kill my Kerbal.  That and just derping around on Kerbin with tiny VTOL hoppers and their carrier boats.

Trying to fly under the R&D building at high speeds is always good fun. Also colliding big ships and stations in orbit is always cool to watch.

Realizing, with just a few days to spare, that in putting together my Eve lander mission, I'd forgotten to include the orbital transfer stage to come home.  My kerbalnaut would be able to get back up into low Eve orbit, but then be stranded there.

Decided that it was a matter of honor that he should have a return stage waiting for him upon arrival at Eve.

Put together the most ridiculously high-dV ship I've ever built.  Ion-powered, lots and lots of drop tanks.

Made the run from Kerbin to Eve in eight days.  That's eight Kerbin days, i.e. 48 hours.

This was pre-1.0, so no reentry heating.  Beat my kerbalnaut to Eve with a few hours to spare, then successfully aerobraked to orbit.

Hitting Eve's atmosphere at several dozen kilometers per second was ... dramatic.

I once set up a Mun Lab and instead of doing science in it I EVA'd both kerbals and used their jetpacks to slide them around the crater the lab was in. Eventually they puffed and I had no Kerbals left : (

In 0.90, building a helicopter with stock parts that could take me to 20 km altitude using nothing but electricity.

To fly:

  1. turn on SAS
  2. hold down the Q key
  3. watch as it lifts off and starts to climb
  4. suppress giggles

Rotates slowly at first.  As it climbs and the air gets thinner, starts spinning faster and faster.  By the time it reaches its operational ceiling of around 20 km, it's spinning so fast it's practically a blur.

The biggest challenge flying it was that it was somewhat unstable-- it had a tendency to "drift" away from the perfectly vertical, which takes some finesse on the controls to nudge it back to true.

Silliness? What are you talking about? What's a silliness? Someone please help.

But really. The silliest thing... probably my latest mission to Laythe, which qualifies as more completely absurd than silly. I was fed up with all that silliness of coming up with a lander that could actually properly gravity turn on Laythe and not end up in a tumble, or run out fuel, and could survive re-entry... so I gave up on all that "orbital rendezvous" nonsense people keep going on about and just built a stage to return to Kerbin from Jool orbit. Then a stage (or two or three) to get that to Laythe escape velocity... then a big, heavy, clunky, terribly built heat shield for Laythe's atmosphere.. then a capture stage, because 1.0's aerodynamics hate me and everything I build, then... I think it's clear by now where this is going. Somehow, I actually managed to launch that monster of a rocket, although I seem to remember just reaching LKO took about an hour. On the attempt that worked. Let's not talk about the failures...

 

Because who needs an efficiency anyways? MOAR BOOSTERS is the answer to every question.
